required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Influence Positive End-expiratory Pressure on Autoregulation in Patients With Respiratory Insufficiency
clinical_study.official_title: Influence of Positive End-expiratory Pressure on the Cerebrovascular Autoregulation in Patients With Respiratory Failure

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of the present study is to characterize the influence of an elevated positive end-expiratory pressure in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome or acute lung injury on the cerebrovascular autoregulation.

detailed_description.textblock: Cerebral blood flow velocity will be measured using transcranial Doppler sonography and then correlate with the invasive arterial blood pressure curve to calculate the index of cerebrovascular autoregulation Mx (Mx>0.3 indicates impaired AR). The index of cerebrovascular autoregulation Mx was measured during baseline positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) levels and after lung recruitment with higher level of PEEP. The equality between this two PEEP levels was estimated and calculated with one side Wilcoxon test.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline cerebrovascular autoregulation due to elevated positive end-expiratory pressure
primary_outcome.description: Is there an impairment of cerebrovascular autoregulation due to positive end-expiratory pressure ventilation this will be a major side effect especial in patients with brain injury.

arm_group.description: patients with respiratory failure and need of high positive end-expiratory pressure ventilation.

intervention.description: Elevation of positive end-expiratory failure for recruitment

study_pop.textblock: Adult patients on intensive care unit with acute respiratory failure

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- respiratory failure
- Age >18 years
- Invasive ventilation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Sepsis
- preexisting cerebral illness
- traumatic brain injury
- meningitis or encephalitis
- pregnancy

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Anesthesiology, University medicine Mainz, Germany
